required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Emotional Freedom Techniques to Reduce Patient Reported Cognitive Complaints in Cancer Survivors
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Wait-list Controlled Trial on the Use of Emotional Freedom Techniques as an Intervention Strategy to Reduce Patient Reported Cognitive Complaints in Cancer Survivors on Behalf of the Belgian Society for Medical Oncology (BSMO)-Cancer Survivorship Taskforce

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to further validate the CDT as a screening tool for identifying elderly cancer patients in need of a more in-depth cognitive evaluation within comprehensive geriatric assessment (CGA) and to validate the pre-defined cut-off score of ≤ 4 according to the Freund scoring system. All geriatric patients that are diagnosed with cancer will be screened by the oncology clinical nurse specialists attached to the respective multi-disciplinary clinics with the VES-13 and G8 questionnaire. Patients that screen positive, will be offered referral to the multi-disciplinary onco-geriatric program where a member of the research team will implement a full geriatric evaluation under supervision of the medical oncologist and/or geriatrician who will then formulate recommendations and might suggest referral to other health care providers. Individual results and survival data of all the patients that have given their informed consent will be registered in a database.

detailed_description.textblock: In this trial the investigators aim to establish whether Emotional Freedom Techniques (EFT) can reduce cognitive complaints in cancer survivors. All consenting patients aged 18 years or above, who have been diagnosed with a solid tumour of hematologic malignancy and who have completed or are in the late phase of a chemotherapy, radiotherapy, anti-hormonal or targeted therapy treatment, can participate in this trial. Patients should suffer from subjective cognitive complaints based on a score of 43 or more on the Cognitive Failure Questionnaire (CFQ). These patients will be randomly assigned to either the control or intervention group. Patients in the intervention group will be scheduled to receive an 8-week EFT intervention program. Other patients will be placed on an 8-week wait list after which patients will also start the EFT program.

primary_outcome.measure: Reduction of cognitive complaints measured by Cognitive Failure Questionnaire

secondary_outcome.measure: Reduction in psychological distress measured by Distress Thermometer
secondary_outcome.description: Reduction in the score on the DT

secondary_outcome.measure: Reduction in fatigue measured by Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy (FACIT)-Fatigue Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Reduction in score on FACIT Fatigue scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Influence on quality of life measured by the European Organisation for the Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire (EORTC QLQ)-C30
secondary_outcome.description: Improvement of the scores on the Global Health scale, functional scale and symptom scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Influence on quality of life measured by EQ-5D
secondary_outcome.description: Improvement on the score on the EQ-5D-3L

secondary_outcome.measure: Influence on longterm quality of life measured by the EuroQol (EQ)-5D
secondary_outcome.description: Improvement on the score on the EQ-5D-3L

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of cancer survivors presenting with cognitive complaints as measured by Cognitive Failure Questionnaire
Influence of age on cognitive complaints in cancer survivors
secondary_outcome.description: Interaction effect of age and CFQ score

secondary_outcome.measure: Influence of gender on cognitive complaints in cancer survivors
secondary_outcome.description: Interaction effect of gender and CFQ score

secondary_outcome.measure: Influence of distress on cognitive complaints in cancer survivors as measured by Distress Thermometer
secondary_outcome.description: Interaction effect of distress and CFQ score

secondary_outcome.measure: Influence of fatigue (FACIT-Fatigue Scale) on cognitive complaints in cancer survivors
secondary_outcome.description: Interaction effect of fatigue and CFQ score

secondary_outcome.measure: Influence of cancer type on cognitive complaints in cancer survivors
secondary_outcome.description: Interaction effect of cancer type and CFQ score

secondary_outcome.measure: Influence of cancer stage on cognitive complaints in cancer survivors
secondary_outcome.description: Interaction effect of cancer stage and CFQ score

secondary_outcome.measure: Influence of the received treatment on cognitive complaints in cancer survivors
secondary_outcome.description: Interaction effect of treatment and CFQ score

arm_group.description: Patients assigned to intervention group receive an 8-week EFT-program
Patients assigned to control group are placed on a waitlist for a period of 8 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients should have reached a minimum age of 18 years at the time of enrolment
- Histologically confirmed diagnosis of a solid cancer or hematologic malignancy
- Patients should have received chemo- or radiotherapy, targeted therapy of hormonal treatment before enrollment (active treatment with anti-hormonal therapy or brachytherapy is allowed)
- Patients can be included in the latest phase of their chemotherapy, radiotherapy, anti-hormonal or targeted therapy treatment
- Patients should have been treated with curative intent or have an expected life expectancy of at least 5 years
- Patients must suffer from subjective cognitive complaints based on the Cognitive Failure Questionnaire (cut-off ≥ 43)
- Patients should be able to adequately communicate in Dutch or French
- Patients should present with a sufficient mental and physical functional status (according to investigator's judgment)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who received a treatment with palliative intent
- Patients showing signs of mental deterioration
- Patients suffering from an organic brain syndrome
- Patients who are alcohol or drug dependent
- Patients with a major psychiatric or neurologic disorder that could potentially invalidate assessment; a prior or current diagnosis of a depressive, anxiety or adjustment disorder is allowed

overall_official.last_name: Philip R Debruyne, MD, PhD, MSc, FRCP
